question: Which of the following is not seen in patent ductus aeriosus?
prompt:
Which of the following is not seen in patent ductus aeriosus?A)Left atrial hyperophy
B)Left ventricular enlargement
C)Continuous murmur
D)Attenuated SI
output0: The correct answer is A)Left atrial hyperophy because it is not a characteristic feature of patent ductus arteriosus. Patent ductus arteriosus is a congenital heart defect that is characterized by a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which results in an abnormal flow of blood.
output1: Left ventricular enlargement is not a characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus. The other options (A, C, and D) are all common findings in this condition.
output2: Patent ductus arteriosus is a congenital heart defect that is characterized by a continuous murmur, which is not seen in patent ductus aeriosus. Patent ductus aeriosus is a type of patent ductus that is not congenital, and it is not associated with a continuous murmur.
output3: The answer is D) Attenuated SI, which is not a characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus. The other options, left atrial hypertrophy, left ventricular enlargement, and continuous murmur, are all common features of patent ductus arteriosus.

question: In Precocious pubey age limit of girls is-
prompt:
In Precocious pubey age limit of girls is-A)8 year
B)10 year
C)9 year
D)11 year
output0: The precocious puberty age limit for girls is 8 years old, as this is the age at which the first signs of puberty typically appear.
output1: The Precocious Puberty Age Limit for girls is 10 years old. This is the age at which girls typically begin to experience early puberty.
output2: The precocious puberty age limit for girls is typically around 9 years old. This is because girls tend to enter puberty earlier than boys, and 9 years old is considered a common age range for the onset of puberty in girls.
output3: The Precocious Puberty Age Limit for girls is 11 years old. This is because girls typically begin puberty between the ages of 8 and 13, and the average age of onset is around 11 years old.

question: Which structure is not preserved in modified radical mastectomy
prompt:
Which structure is not preserved in modified radical mastectomyA)Cephalic vein
B)Pectoralis minor
C)Pectoralis major
D)Branches of lntercostobrachial N.
output0: The Cephalic vein is not preserved in a modified radical mastectomy. This is because the Cephalic vein is a superficial vein that is not essential for the surgical procedure.
output1: The Pectoralis minor muscle is not preserved in a modified radical mastectomy. This surgical procedure involves the removal of the breast, skin, and underlying tissue, but does not involve the Pectoralis minor muscle.
output2: The Pectoralis major muscle is not preserved in a modified radical mastectomy. This surgical procedure is used to remove the breast and any affected lymph nodes, but it does not involve the Pectoralis major muscle.
output3: The branches of the intercostobrachial nerve are not preserved in a modified radical mastectomy. This is because the intercostobrachial nerve is not a vital structure, and its preservation is not necessary for the success of the surgery.

question: A 42-year-old man presents to establish care with a family physician after having progressively worsening back pain. He has recently migrated from Sweden and has not had any checkups in the last 3 years. He first started having back pain 3 years ago, but his pain has begun to be excruciating in the mornings. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels stiff every morning and this usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour. Both of his knees are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his hands for long periods of time due to joint pain and stiffness. His father and sister also have joint issues, and his mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis. He has been a smoker for 13 years. Upon physical examination, his wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
correct_answer: Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies
options: A)Testing for serum Ca and PTH
C)Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies
prompt:
A 42-year-old man presents to establish care with a family physician after having progressively worsening back pain. He has recently migrated from Sweden and has not had any checkups in the last 3 years. He first started having back pain 3 years ago, but his pain has begun to be excruciating in the mornings. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels stiff every morning and this usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour. Both of his knees are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his hands for long periods of time due to joint pain and stiffness. His father and sister also have joint issues, and his mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis. He has been a smoker for 13 years. Upon physical examination, his wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following is the next best step in management?A)Testing for serum Ca and PTH
B)Calcium and Vitamin D prescription
C)Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies
D)Testing for serum ferritin
output0: The next best step in management for this patient would be to test for serum calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. This is because the patient's symptoms of worsening back pain, morning stiffness, and joint pain are consistent with hyperparathyroidism, a condition in which the parathyroid glands produce too much PTH. Elevated calcium levels and low PTH levels would support this diagnosis.
output1: The patient's symptoms of back pain, joint pain, and morning stiffness are consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis or a rheumatoid arthritis flare. The patient's history of smoking and family history of joint issues also support this diagnosis. The next best step in management would be to prescribe calcium and vitamin D to help prevent further bone loss and manage the patient's symptoms.
output2: The patient's symptoms of morning stiffness, joint pain, and swelling in the wrists and PIP joints are consistent with seronegative spondyloarthropathy, such as psoriatic arthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies would be the next best step in management to help confirm the diagnosis.
output3: The patient's symptoms of morning stiffness and pain in multiple joints are consistent with inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The presence of warm and swollen wrist and PIP joints also supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's history of smoking and family history of joint issues increase the likelihood of an inflammatory condition. Therefore, the next best step in management would be to test for serum ferritin, as elevated levels of this protein are commonly found in patients with RA.

question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a new-onset seizure. The patient was at home watching television when she suddenly began jerking her limbs and not responding according to her partner. The patient works as a gardener is often dehydrated but drinks large volumes of water to compensate for her work. She does not wear protective gear or sunscreen while working. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. She drinks liquor before bed every night. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes and recently lost 9 pounds. Physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?
correct_answer: Small cell carcinoma of the lung
options: B)Infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast
D)Small cell carcinoma of the lung
prompt:
A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a new-onset seizure. The patient was at home watching television when she suddenly began jerking her limbs and not responding according to her partner. The patient works as a gardener is often dehydrated but drinks large volumes of water to compensate for her work. She does not wear protective gear or sunscreen while working. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. She drinks liquor before bed every night. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes and recently lost 9 pounds. Physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?A)Glioblastoma multiforme
B)Infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast
C)Primary seizure disorder
D)Small cell carcinoma of the lung
output0: The most likely underlying diagnosis in this patient is Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) based on the patient's symptoms of a new-onset seizure, history of smoking, and recent weight loss. GBM is a type of brain cancer that typically affects older adults and is associated with these risk factors. The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes also increase the likelihood of GBM. The other options are less likely given the patient's symptoms and history.
output1: The most likely underlying diagnosis for this patient is infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast, based on the history of a new-onset seizure. This is a rare presentation of breast cancer, and the patient's age and past medical history increase her risk for this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's history of smoking and alcohol consumption are risk factors for breast cancer.
output2: The most likely underlying diagnosis in this patient is primary seizure disorder due to the sudden onset of jerking limbs and loss of responsiveness. The patient's history of smoking, alcohol consumption, and dehydration are all risk factors for seizures. Additionally, the patient's past medical history of hypertension and diabetes increases the likelihood of a seizure disorder. While glioblastoma multiforme, infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast, and small cell carcinoma of the lung are all possible diagnoses, they are less likely given the patient's age and symptoms.
output3:
The most likely underlying diagnosis in this patient is small cell carcinoma of the lung due to the following reasons:
 1. Age: 65 years old, which is within the age range for small cell lung cancer.
 2. Smoking history: 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day for 40 years, which is a significant risk factor for developing lung cancer.
 3. Weight loss: 9 pounds lost recently, which is a common symptom of lung cancer.
 4. No other obvious risk factors for seizures.

question: What is the mental disorder that most frequently appears comorbid with bulimia nervosa ?:
prompt:
What is the mental disorder that most frequently appears comorbid with bulimia nervosa ?:A)Mood disorder
B)Post-traumatic stress disorder
C)Substance dependence
D)Panic disorder
output0: The mental disorder that most frequently appears comorbid with bulimia nervosa is mood disorder. Bulimia nervosa is often associated with depression, anxiety, and other mood disorders.
output1: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is commonly comorbid with bulimia nervosa. Research suggests that individuals with bulimia nervosa are more likely to experience PTSD than the general population. The trauma associated with bulimia nervosa may contribute to the development of PTSD.
output2: The mental disorder that most frequently appears comorbid with bulimia nervosa is substance dependence. Many individuals with bulimia nervosa also struggle with addiction to drugs or alcohol, which can exacerbate their eating disorder.
output3: Panic disorder is the most common mental disorder that appears comorbid with bulimia nervosa. Research suggests that individuals with bulimia nervosa are at an increased risk of developing panic disorder, and vice versa. Both conditions are characterized by symptoms of anxiety and fear, and individuals with one condition may be more likely to develop the other.

question: Aneurysm (arterial aneurysm) often leads to following what form of stroke?
prompt:
Aneurysm (arterial aneurysm) often leads to following what form of stroke?A)Thalamus (thalamus) bleeding
B)Under the cerebral cortex (subcortical) bleeding
C)The arachnoid (subarachnoid) hemorrhage
D)Cerebellum (cerebellum) bleeding
output0: Arterial aneurysms are a type of vascular malformation that can lead to stroke. When an aneurysm ruptures, it can cause bleeding in the brain, which can lead to a thalamus stroke. The thalamus is a structure in the midbrain that plays a critical role in sensory processing and regulation of consciousness.
output1: Arterial aneurysms often lead to subcortical bleeding, which can cause a variety of cognitive and behavioral changes. This type of stroke is often referred to as a "silent stroke" because the symptoms may not be immediately apparent.
output2: Arterial aneurysms can lead to a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is the most common form of stroke caused by an aneurysm. This type of stroke occurs when the aneurysm ruptures and bleeds into the space between the brain and the thin membrane that covers it (the arachnoid membrane).
output3: Arterial aneurysms can lead to cerebellar hemorrhage, which is a type of stroke that occurs when there is bleeding in the cerebellum. This can cause a range of symptoms, including weakness, numbness, and difficulty with coordination and balance.

question: Candidal infection in HIV resistant to fluconazole is treated with?
prompt:
Candidal infection in HIV resistant to fluconazole is treated with?A)Nystatin
B)Amphotericin B
C)Itraconazole
D)Clotrimazole
output0: Nystatin is effective against Candida infections in HIV patients who are resistant to fluconazole. Nystatin is a polyene antifungal medication that works by inhibiting the synthesis of the fungal cell membrane. It is often used as an alternative to fluconazole in these cases.
output1: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that is effective against Candida infections, including those caused by resistant strains in HIV patients. It works by disrupting the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death.
output2: Itraconazole is effective against HIV-associated candidiasis, including infections that are resistant to fluconazole. It is also effective against other types of fungal infections, such as aspergillosis and histoplasmosis.
output3: Clotrimazole is effective against Candida infections that are resistant to fluconazole. It is a broad-spectrum antifungal medication that is effective against a wide range of fungal infections, including those caused by resistant strains of Candida.

question: After load is decreased by ?
prompt:
After load is decreased by ?A)Exercise
B)Anemia
C)Thyrotoxicosis
D)All of the above
output0: Exercise is a well-known factor that can help decrease anxiety and improve mood. Physical activity has been shown to increase the release of endorphins, which are the body's natural painkillers and mood elevators. Additionally, exercise has been linked to improved self-esteem, better sleep quality, and reduced stress levels.
output1: After load is decreased by anemia, as the heart has to work harder to compensate for the decreased oxygen delivery to the tissues, leading to increased cardiac output and blood pressure.
output2: Thyrotoxicosis, a condition characterized by an overactive thyroid gland, can lead to increased heart rate and cardiac output, which can result in a decrease in afterload.
output3: All of the options listed (exercise, anemia, thyrotoxicosis) can cause a decrease in afterload. Afterload is the pressure in the systemic circulation that opposes the heart's ejection of blood.

question: Drug not given in PCOD in a 30-year-old lady with infeility?
prompt:
Drug not given in PCOD in a 30-year-old lady with infeility?A)Clomiphene
B)Tamoxifen
C)OCPs
D)Metformin
output0: Clomiphene is the most effective medication for treating polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is a common cause of infertility in women. It works by stimulating ovulation and can help improve menstrual cycles and fertility.
output1: Tamoxifen is not typically used to treat polycystic ovary disease (PCOD) or infertility. Clomiphene is the most commonly used medication for this purpose.
output2: OCPs (oral contraceptives) are not typically used to treat PCOD (polycystic ovary disease). Clomiphene, Tamoxifen, and Metformin are all potential treatments for PCOD, but they are not OCPs.
output3: Metformin is not typically used to treat infertility in women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOD). Clomiphene is the first-line medication for ovulation induction in women with PCOD. Tamoxifen is not commonly used for infertility treatment. OCPs (oral contraceptives) are not effective for treating infertility in PCOD.
